body: Hi @naugustin - can you share a reproducing example that we can run?  The test output helps, but being able to replay your problem locally is a lot better :slightly_smiling_face:

Thank you.

I mimicked my fixture order with simple script. I am able to reproduce it. please find attached the script. Simply unzip under c:\ and run below command.
[test.zip](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/files/5053060/test.zip)

```
pytest -s -v --show-capture=no \test\test\tests\dummy_test.py
============================= test session starts =============================
platform win32 -- Python 3.7.0, pytest-6.0.1, py-1.9.0, pluggy-0.13.1 -- c:\prog
ram files (x86)\python37-32\python.exe
cachedir: .pytest_cache
metadata: {'Python': '3.7.0', 'Platform': 'Windows-2008ServerR2-6.1.7601-SP1', '
Packages': {'pytest': '6.0.1', 'py': '1.9.0', 'pluggy': '0.13.1'}, 'Plugins': {'
html': '2.1.1', 'metadata': '1.10.0'}}
rootdir: C:\
plugins: html-2.1.1, metadata-1.10.0
collected 1 item

..\..\::test_dummy ERROR

=================================== ERRORS ====================================
________________________ ERROR at setup of test_dummy _________________________
file C:\test\test\tests\dummy_test.py, line 9
  def test_dummy(session_fixture2):
E       fixture 'session_fixture2' not found
>       available fixtures: cache, capfd, capfdbinary, caplog, capsys, capsysbin
ary, doctest_namespace, extra, metadata, module_fixture, monkeypatch, pytestconf
ig, record_property, record_testsuite_property, record_xml_attribute, recwarn, t
mp_path, tmp_path_factory, tmpdir, tmpdir_factory
>       use 'pytest --fixtures [testpath]' for help on them.

C:\test\test\tests\dummy_test.py:9
=========================== short test summary info ===========================
ERROR ..\..\::test_dummy
============================== 1 error in 0.03s ===============================
```
can you try with pytest master, i recall that @bluetech just recently landed some enhancements for path handling that might help that (i don't have a windows box)

I can reproduce the problem even with current `master`. The key to make this fail is to use an absolute path but without the drive letter:

```
d:\projects\pytest (HEAD detached at 92af2e2 -> origin)
(.env37) Î» pytest \projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py
==fails==
```

Including the drive letter the test passes:

```
d:\projects\pytest (master -> origin)
(.env37) Î» pytest d:\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py
==passes==
```

I can investigate this later. ðŸ‘

Quick hunch in case somebody wants to investigate this before me:

```python
>>> from pathlib import Path
>>> Path(r'd:\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py') == Path(r'\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py')
False
>>> Path(r'd:\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py') == Path(r'\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py').absolute()
True
```
@naugustin meanwhile a workaround is to pass the full path including the drive letter.

Thank you.

Yes. it works if i specify the test file starting with C:\

I ran the code from above in Python 3.8.5 and could not reproduce the results. Both comparisons result in False. I ran this in the context of my C: drive.
```
>>> from pathlib import Path
>>> Path(r'd:\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py') == Path(r'\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py')
False
>>> Path(r'd:\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py') == Path(r'\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py').absolute()
False
>>> Path(r'd:\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py')
WindowsPath('d:/projects/pytest/.tmp/drive/tests/dummy_test.py')
>>>Path(r'\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py')
WindowsPath('/projects/pytest/.tmp/drive/tests/dummy_test.py')
>>> Path(r'\projects\pytest\.tmp\drive\tests\dummy_test.py').absolute()
WindowsPath('C:/projects/pytest/.tmp/drive/tests/dummy_test.py')
```
Also running `pytest` in the directory of the extracted `test.zip` provided above discovers a test in `tests\dummy_test.py` which passes.

> . Both comparisons result in False. I ran this in the context of my C: drive.

You need to be in the same drive as the drives of the paths being used. If you are on the C: drive, you should use `C:` paths, because `absolute()` will use the current directory to construct the full path. In the examples above, just replace `d:` by `c:` and you will see the same results.

> Also running pytest in the directory of the extracted test.zip provided above discovers a test in tests\dummy_test.py which passes.

It is important to pass the *full path without a drive letter* to pytest, so if you extracted that zip to `C:\temp`, you need to execute pytest from the C: drive and pass `\temp\tests` to it.

issue.title: Fix Module.name from full path without drive letter

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing
